hypothesis: PINNs can directly optimize for heat source parameters by encoding physics constraints in the loss.

tuning_runs.result: ABORTED - PINN requires efficient gradients which we can't obtain

findings.lbfgsb_test: 0.0988 RMSE, 74.5s per sample, 99.4 min projected for 80 samples (over budget)
findings.nm_test: 0.1155 RMSE, 32.6s per sample, 43.5 min projected (within budget)
findings.gradient_problem: Finite differences require O(2n) sims per gradient, 2.3x slower than NM

tuning_runs.notes: PINN would need efficient gradients. Three approaches all failed: (1) Adjoint - wrong gradients, (2) JAX autodiff - stability constraint, (3) Finite differences - too slow

final_result: ABORTED - PINN requires efficient gradient computation. Adjoint method failed (gradients 1e-6 wrong). JAX autodiff failed (explicit Euler stability). Finite differences too slow (99 min vs 60 min budget). Nelder-Mead remains optimal for this problem.
